text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Centre Party and the ruling Social Democrats now neck-and- neck as two biggest parties after European parliament and local elections.
- Courts in different parts of the country hand down different punishments for similar criminal offences, polls show.
- A clear majority of Finns think alcohol should be on sale in ordinary supermarkets, but 20 per cent say strong spirits should not be avaliable, polls show. @
- Majority of adult education experts say job-seekers should be obliged to satisfy minimum proficiency criteria before being offered jobs.
- Insurance group Sampo gets court order to pay compensation for illegal dismissals.
- Over half of the world's spoken languages face risk of extinction in coming decades, says Australian professor.
- Overall performance of ruling Social Democrats in local and EU elections indicates the party's support is waning among voters - editorial. @
KAUPPALEHTI
- In the next few years more funds will flow into life insurance, expected to boost insurance companies' shares.
- Insurance group Sampo to derive huge benefits as overall value of sister company Kaleva is transferred to newly formed Henki-Sampo.
- Many business people made significant gains in local elections. More than 1,000 of total 2,500 elected candidates are business people. @
DEMARI
- Low election turnout in urban centres explains poor performance of ruling Social Democrats.
- Centre Party member of parliament Mikko Pesala emerges as strong favourite of vice-speaker of parliament to replace Sirkka-Liisa Antil who leaves for Brussels.
AAMULEHTI
- Famous BBC symphony orchestra finally makes an appearance in Tampere after 66 years of existence.
- Forest industry shows growing concern over diminishing forest reserves, even though wood cutting in Finland is far below forest growth rate. @
TURUN SANOMAT
- Low turnout of unemployed behind overall low showing for Europoll, statistics show.
